content: @BWPanda (Peter) I can't seem to get the 1.x-2.x branch to work, had to downgrade to 1.x-1.x. What's the trick? I tried using the form ID with dashes and then with underscores but it doesn't seem to take.
Make sure its the actual hidden form id value, not the CSS id.

Maybe I'm not understanding what that is. The form HTML comes out like this (default comment form):

<form id="comment-form" class="comment-node-post-form comment-form user-info-from-cookie antibot" action="/antibot" method="post" accept-charset="UTF-8">

I've tried both comment-form and comment_form but neither seemed to work.

@Laryn Here's an example of a Backdrop form:
image.png
The form ID is: comment_node_post_form as per the highlighted line. Note how the hidden form_id element value is different from the CSS ID.

I've learned something new. And now that you've explained it the help text seems pretty clear when I re-read it. I was going to put some of the details in the wiki but it's turned off for that module -- is that intentional?
@BWPanda (Peter) ++
(peter)** :-) (Karma: 25)
I think the wiki has to be turned on per project.
I turn off the wiki on my projects as I've never seen a need for it. Issues or the README usually suffices.
Ok. BTW, I'm really liking the 2.x version!
:thumbs_up: Glad to hear it :blush:
I see by the message of the last commit that support for webforms has been added. What else is different in 2.x @BWPanda (Peter) ?

...btw, I've never seen cases being repeated in switch like in https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/compact_forms/blob/1.x-2.x/compact_forms.module#L123 ...what sort of witchcraft is that?

backdrop-contrib/compact_forms
Presents text fields for selected forms in a more compact fashion using jQuery. - backdrop-contrib/compact_forms
Compact Forms has been re-written to be simpler and to use form #placeholder properties instead of overlaying the label on the field.
@klonos see the description on the 2.0.0 release for more detail :wait_one_second:️
Thanks. Just did :+1:

Yeah, 1.x basically moved the field label on top of the field and then used JS to show/hide it. I found I always had to add styling to make it look half decent. 2.x uses placeholder text instead, so no JS needed and forms look nice OOTB.

As for switch statements, that is how they work, and is why you normally need to add a break; at the end of each (to prevent them following-through to each other). It's also why it works when you do this:

switch (condition) {
  case 1:
  case 2:
  case 3:
    // Do something for cases 1, 2 & 3.
  break;
}
This looks like a good explanation if you're interested: http://phpswitch.com/
Thanks ...reading :eyes:
Yeah, it seems that I have been using the simplest way of switch/case ...good to know that it can be used to achieve more. @BWPanda (Peter)++
(peter)** kudos (Karma: 26)

@Laryn Can you tell me what forms you've activated in https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/compact_forms/issues/8 ?

Notice: Undefined index: #type in _compact_forms_process_fields() · Issue #8 · backdrop-contrib/compact_forms
I'm seeing this in the logs after upgrading to the latest version and clearing caches: Notice: Undefined index: #type in _compact_forms_process_fields() (line 123 of /path/modules/contrib/compa...
I'm trying to reproduce...
(Hmm, just realised that statement could be taken out of context...)
On the site in question the only form activated is webform_client_form_xx

BWPanda (Peter) said:

I'm trying to reproduce...

Stop bothering the man @Laryn, cant you see he is busy?
